title: The Divided Kingdom
shortSummary: 1 Kings 12 recounts the pivotal moment when the united kingdom of Israel splits into two separate nations after Solomon's death. Rehoboam's harsh response to the people's plea for relief leads to the rebellion of the ten northern tribes under Jeroboam, fulfilling God's earlier prophecy. This chapter highlights the consequences of pride and disobedience, as well as God's sovereign control over history.
timeline: c. 931 BC - Division of the United Kingdom after Solomon's reign

keyCharacters.name: Rehoboam
keyCharacters.description: Son of Solomon and king of Judah whose refusal to lighten the people's burden leads to the kingdom's division.

keyCharacters.name: Jeroboam
keyCharacters.description: Former servant of Solomon who becomes king over the northern tribes of Israel after their rebellion.

keyCharacters.name: Shemaiah
keyCharacters.description: A man of God who delivers God's command to Rehoboam and the people, instructing them not to fight their brethren.

keyCharacters.name: Adoram
keyCharacters.description: Overseer of tribute under Rehoboam who is killed by the rebellious Israelites.

definitions.definition: A wooden frame placed on the necks of oxen for work; metaphorically represents burdens or oppression.
Elevated sites used for worship, often associated with idolatry and unauthorized religious practices.
Used metaphorically here to describe harsher punishment than whips, symbolizing severe oppression.
Idols made by Jeroboam to prevent Israelites from worshiping in Jerusalem, leading to sin and idolatry.

outline.heading: Rehoboam’s Ascension and the People’s Request
outline.description: The people of Israel gather at Shechem to make Rehoboam king and request relief from Solomon’s heavy burdens, setting the stage for conflict.

outline.heading: Rehoboam’s Counsel and Harsh Response
outline.description: Rehoboam rejects the wise counsel of the elders and follows the advice of his peers, responding with increased harshness, which leads to rebellion.

outline.heading: The Kingdom Divides
outline.description: The ten northern tribes reject Rehoboam’s rule, making Jeroboam king; Rehoboam prepares for war but is commanded by God through Shemaiah to desist.

outline.heading: Jeroboam’s Idolatrous Measures
outline.description: Jeroboam establishes new worship centers with golden calves and unauthorized priests to prevent his people from returning to Jerusalem, leading Israel into sin.

application: Seek and heed godly counsel rather than relying on worldly advice, especially in leadership decisions.
Recognize the consequences of pride and harshness in relationships and leadership, striving instead for humility and compassion.
Trust in God’s sovereign plan even when circumstances seem difficult or divisive.
Guard against idolatry in all forms and remain faithful to true worship of the Lord.

keyVerses.text: And they spake unto him, saying, If thou wilt be a servant unto this people this day, and wilt serve them, and answer them, and speak good words to them, then they will be thy servants for ever.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the wisdom of servant leadership and the importance of humility in ruling God's people.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore the king hearkened not unto the people; for the cause was from the LORD, that he might perform his saying, which the LORD spake by Ahijah the Shilonite unto Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's sovereignty in the kingdom's division as a fulfillment of prophecy despite human disobedience.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD, Ye shall not go up, nor fight against your brethren the children of Israel: return every man to his house; for this thing is from me. They hearkened therefore to the word of the LORD, and returned to depart, according to the word of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: God’s command for peace between divided brethren shows His authority over conflict and His desire for obedience.

keyVerses.text: And this thing became a sin: for the people went to worship before the one, even unto Dan.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the beginning of idolatry in the northern kingdom, emphasizing the danger of false worship.
